Itâ€™s qualifying in Bahrain, 2018 - Sebastian Vettel pulls his Ferrari onto the grid after securing pole position. Heâ€™s all smiles, his car perfectly positioned for a victory. 

But as the cameras zoom in for the celebration, they see something unusual on the Ferrariâ€™s steering wheel. There, mounted on the right side of Vettel's steering wheel, sits a third paddle. Not the standard clutch and gear-change paddles every driver uses, but something else. 

Today, we're going inside the most complex piece of equipment any racing driver touchesâ€”the Formula One steering wheel. 

And I managed to get access to the Racing Bulls factory, where their Head of Electronics walked me through twenty years of steering wheel evolution and showed me the secrets that most people never get to see. 

We'll uncover how teams have pushed the boundaries of what's legal, what's possible, and what borders on genius.

Mercedes have made a huge mistake this seasonâ€¦ a suspension upgrade that was supposed to solve their biggest problem - but instead, it put them months behind and cost them a load of championship points.

Before this upgrade, George Russell had four podiums in six races. After? Just two podiums in the next eight rounds. 

And Kimi Antonelli went from scoring points regularly to struggling to even get out of Q1. But what was this change, and how could Mercedes get it so wrong?

https://youtu.be/CQCSDRp0pRE

Why F1 Teams Spend Â£8m on Simulators (I drove one)
https://youtu.be/FPxoXtR9DxE

Why Itâ€™s Almost Impossible to Rev to 21,000 RPM
https://youtu.be/NokXiX-aznM

How F1 Brakes Stop from 200mph to 0 in 4 Seconds 
https://youtu.be/N2NyxdBNFe0

Formula One teams spend over Â£1.5 billion a year engineering just 10 cars. Four thousand of the world's best engineers work to find thousandths of a second on track.

Over the last year, I've had unprecedented access to F1 teams and their suppliers â€“ inside the factories where these impossible machines are built.

From the Â£50,000 pistons to the Â£250,000 gearboxes, from carbon brakes that take three months to manufacture to front wings that require a week of continuous production.

This documentary takes you inside the world's most advanced racing machinery. So, how do you build something that operates at the absolute limit of physics?

Let's find out.

https://youtu.be/m91v8HNZtTw

https://youtu.be/AABg_KZbNiA

When F1 Ran At The NURBURGRING (And Was Fast)
https://youtu.be/EVUFiximfKc

This Formula 1 car is so crazy, so fundamentally different, that rival teams banned it before it ever got to race.

The car Iâ€™m sitting in here is the Lotus Type 88. 

Now you might look at this and think - okay, it's just another F1 car from the 1980s. But you'd be wrong. 

This thing has something no other F1 car has had before or since. Two chassis. Not six wheels, not a huge fan - but basically two separate cars, working together as one.

Why F1 Teams Spend Â£8m on Simulators (I drove one)
https://youtu.be/FPxoXtR9DxE

How Formula 1 Gearboxes Work (F1 team explains)
https://youtu.be/ayeZerNpQbE

How Formula 1 Pistons Are Made (I went to the factory)
https://youtu.be/IY9GDDtEfKQ

What's Inside a Â£250,000 F1 Gearbox?
https://youtu.be/dIvuZKBDj3E

How Â£100,000 F1 Brakes Are Made (Factory Visit)
https://youtu.be/yKDVB37AOic

This is Racing Bulls' $3 million simulator in Faenza, Italy - and it's so accurate that after Friday practice - on the real track, they'll run the exact same car setup here virtually, test changes that would be impossible on track, and if the sim says it's faster... those changes go straight onto the real car for Saturday.

The engineering behind it is absolutely wild. So in this video, I'm going deep on how these simulators actually work, why teams trust them enough to bet race results on them, and of course... I'm going to drive it and see how close I can get to their driversâ€™ lap times.

F1 callipers go from this raw block of metal to these absolute masterpieces. And discs from looking like this, to a beautifully engineered piece of carbon. 

Now, theyâ€™re expensiveâ€¦ the entire braking system, all the parts supplied by Brembo, costs just less than Â£100,000 â€“  but,  there's a good reason for thatâ€¦ They stop an F1 car from 200 mph to 60 in just 3 seconds.

But I wanted to understand HOW the world's most impressive brakes are actually made.

So, when I got access to Brembo â€“ the company that supplies every single F1 team with brake callipers and half the grid with carbon brake discs â€“ I had to go.

McLaren are doing something very unusual with their suspension, in fact they might not be using it at all. 

They just won in Austria in dominant fashion. While everyone else's tyres cooked, McLaren's stayed perfect for the entire race distance - and this is their big advantage. 

So, I decided to investigate what's really going on.

title: How Fast Before F1 Becomes Undriveable?
description:
ğŸ’¡ To try everything Brilliant has to offer for free, visit https://brilliant.org/DRIVER61. Youâ€™ll also get 20% off an annual premium subscription!

ğŸ’¨ ğŸï¸  Join the waitlist for our motorsport engineering courses: https://bit.ly/4moJ6d1

How Fast Could Cars Theoretically Accelerate?
https://youtu.be/hy_IieLVAvQ

What If F1 ENGINES Had No Rules?
https://youtu.be/MlKOrg0zpKY

0-1000 mph in 22 Seconds
https://youtu.be/FTJ-lgFimZA

How This Car Does 0-100 in 0.9 Sec
https://youtu.be/kb1yk_068Kc

What If Formula 1 Had No Rules?
https://youtu.be/m91v8HNZtTw

How fast would an F1 car need to go before it's simply too fast for a human to drive? It's a fascinating question, and one that keeps coming up in the comments of our videos about cars that are quicker than F1.

So, I decided to find out. I've spoken with a G-force specialist to understand the absolute limits of what the human body can handle in a corner, whether our reaction times would still work at insane speeds, and if our brains could even process what's happening at 400 mph through Eau Rouge.

And what I found out surprised me.

title: How F1 Drivers Survive Stopping 200 to 0 MPH in 0.5 Seconds

What happens to F1 drivers when they have massive crashes?

For example, Romain Grosjean went through 67G in his horrendous shunt in Bahrain, and some drivers have got even higher in the past... but how do drivers survive, and what goes on inside their bodies and heads?

Well, I wanted to find out how much danger drivers are really in... because it's something that I've experienced myself.

title: McLarenâ€™s GENIUS Tyre Trick Explained
description:

https://youtu.be/cx90r2O6Dcw

How Formula 1 Brakes Work (F1 team explains)
https://youtu.be/oHRkLqmZa6c

McLaren has a tyre advantage that's baffling the paddock. While other teams watch their tyres overheat and performance drop off, McLaren somehow keeps their rubber in the perfect operating window lap after lap.

Red Bull suspects water cooling. They reportedly have thermal images showing "cold spots" on McLaren's brake drums, to which McLaren basically said protest us!

But what's their secret? Well, the answer might lie in something called phase change materials. And to find out more - I spoke with Martin Buchan, who was an F1 engineer, and wrote his thesis at McLaren about this exact technology eight years ago.

Some F1 teams spend up to $350 million a year, which is a massive amount of money - and much more than the official $135 million budget cap. 

So, whatâ€™s going on? Well, I spoke to Guenther Steiner to really understand how much F1 teams are spending.

In this video, we'll dive into the incredible money that makes F1 teams work â€“ where the money comes from, where it goes, and why the gap between top teams and the rest remains so wide despite the cost cap.

I just got an incredible phone call. 

And itâ€™s going to help me answer one of my biggest doubtsâ€¦  could I really have made it to the very top level of racing? 

Well, I just got a call from Formula E to go and test a car in Miami, and there's going to be 11 Formula E drivers, including 6 whoâ€™ve raced or tested in F1... in the same cars.

Appart from being a load of fun, it means, for the first time, I'll be able to compare myself directly against world-class drivers. And finally, have an idea if I'm really good enough. 

So, let's see whatâ€™s going to happen when I get dropped into a world championship race teamâ€¦

A Formula 1 driver can spend over Â£100,000 on helmets each year, and theyâ€™re said to be bulletproof. So, I went to Italy to see how F1 helmets are made, and to a shooting range to see if they are indeed bulletproof. 

Stilo, who make helmets for a number of F1 drivers, gave me unprecedented access to their factory to see the entire process of creating an F1 helmet, from design, manufacturing, and testing - and it genuinely was one of the most fascinating things Iâ€™ve ever seen.

So, where do you start when designing a helmet that saves lives? Not from the outside, but from the inside.
